org.gearvrf

Class GVRSceneObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRSceneObject
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IEventReceiver, PrettyPrint, IScriptable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GVRAccessiblityObject, GVRCameraSceneObject, GVRCubeSceneObject, GVRCylinderSceneObject, GVRGearControllerSceneObject, GVRKeyboardSceneObject, GVRLineSceneObject, GVRModelSceneObject, GVRSphereSceneObject, GVRTextViewSceneObject, GVRVideoSceneObject, GVRViewSceneObject, GVRWebViewSceneObject

    public class GVRSceneObject
extends GVRHybridObject
implements PrettyPrint, IScriptable, IEventReceiver
    Describes a 3D object in the scene with a position and orientation. Every scene object has a location, and can have children. An invisible scene object can be used to move a set of scene as a unit, preserving their relative geometry. Invisible scene objects don't need any render data.

    Visible scene objects must have render data attached. Each GVRRenderData has a GL mesh that defines its geometry, and a GVRMaterial that defines its surface.

    Components can be attached to a scene object to extend its functionality. For example, you can attach a light component to make the scene object illuminate other objects. Only one component of a particular type can be attached. Components are retrieved based on their type.

    GVRSceneObject receives events defined in ISceneObjectEvents. To add a listener to these events, use the following code: 

         ISceneObjectEvents myEventListener = new ISceneObjectEvents() {
         ...
     };
     getEventReceiver().addListener(myEventListener);

      • GVRSceneObject

        public GVRSceneObject(GVRContext gvrContext,
                      java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRMesh> futureMesh,
                      java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> futureTexture)
        Very high-level constructor that asynchronously loads the mesh and texture. Note that because of asynchronous request consolidation you generally don't have to do anything special to create several objects that share the same mesh or texture: if you create all the objects in onInit(), the meshes and textures will generally not have loaded before your onInit() method finishes. Thus, the loading code will see that, say, sceneObject2 and sceneObject3 are using the same mesh as sceneObject1, and will only load the mesh once.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - current GVRContext.
        futureMesh - mesh of the object.
        futureTexture - texture of the object.
        Since:
        1.6.8

      • GVRSceneObject

        public GVRSceneObject(GVRContext gvrContext,
                      GVRAndroidResource mesh,
                      GVRAndroidResource texture)
        Very high-level constructor that asynchronously loads the mesh and texture.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - current GVRContext.
        mesh - Basically, a stream containing a mesh file.
        texture - Basically, a stream containing a texture file. This can be either a compressed texture or a regular Android bitmap file.
        Since:
        1.6.7

      • attachComponent

        public boolean attachComponent(GVRComponent component)
        Attach a component to this scene object. Each scene object has a list of components that may be attached to it. Only one component of a particular type can be attached. Components are retrieved based on their type.
        Parameters:
        component - component to attach.
        Returns:
        true if component is attached, false if a component of that class is already attached.

        public void detachTransform()
        Remove the object's transform. After this call, the object will have no transformations associated with it.

      • getTransform

        public GVRTransform getTransform()
        Get the GVRTransform. A GVRTransform encapsulates a 4x4 matrix that specifies how to render the GL mesh: transform methods let you move, rotate, and scale your scene object.
        Returns:
        The current transform. If no transform is currently attached to the object, returns null.

      • attachRenderData

        public void attachRenderData(GVRRenderData renderData)
        Attach rendering data to the object. If other rendering data is currently attached, it is replaced with the new data. GVRRenderData contains the GL mesh, the texture, the shader id, and various shader constants.
        Parameters:
        renderData - New rendering data.

      • detachRenderData

        public void detachRenderData()
        Detach the object's current rendering data. An object with no GVRRenderData is not visible.

      • getRenderData

        public GVRRenderData getRenderData()
        Get the current GVRRenderData.
        Returns:
        The current rendering data. If no rendering data is currently attached to the object, returns null.

      • hasMesh

        public boolean hasMesh()
        Checks if this GVRSceneObject has mesh. This method is not recursive. That is, if it doesn't have a mesh though its children have, it returns false.
        Returns:
        true if this GVRSceneObject contains mesh itself.

      • setPickingEnabled

        public void setPickingEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Simple, high-level API to enable or disable eye picking for this scene object. The low-level API gives you a lot of control over eye picking, but it does involve an awful lot of details. This method (and getPickingEnabled()) provides a simple boolean property. It attaches a GVRSphereCollider to the scene object. If you want more accurate picking, you can use attachComponent(GVRComponent)} to attach a mesh collider instead. The mesh collider is more accurate but also costs more to compute.
        Parameters:
        enabled - Should eye picking 'see' this scene object?
        Since:
        2.0.2
        See Also:
        GVRSphereCollider, GVRMeshCollider

      • getPickingEnabled

        public boolean getPickingEnabled()
        Is eye picking enabled for this scene object?
        Returns:
        Whether eye picking can 'see' this scene object?
        Since:
        2.0.2

      • addChildObject

        public void addChildObject(GVRComponent childComponent)
        Add the owner of childComponent as a child of this object. (owner object of the Adding a child will increase the getChildrenCount() for this scene object. If the component is not attached to a scene object this function does nothing.
        Parameters:
        childComponent - Component whose owner is added as a child of this object.

      • removeChildObject

        public void removeChildObject(GVRComponent childComponent)
        Remove the owner of childComponent as a child of this object. Removing a child will decrease the getChildrenCount() for this scene object. If the component is not attached to a scene object this function does nothing.
        Parameters:
        childComponent - Component whose owner is removeed as a child of this object.

      • forAllDescendants

        public void forAllDescendants(GVRSceneObject.SceneVisitor visitor)
        Visits all the descendants of this scene object. The SceneVisitor.visit function is called for every descendant until it returns false. This allows you to traverse the scene graph safely without copying it. This method gives much better performance than iterating children() or getChildren().
        Parameters:
        visitor - SceneVisitor interface implementing "visit" function
        See Also:
        children(), getChildren(), GVRSceneObject.SceneVisitor, forAllComponents(ComponentVisitor), forAllComponents(ComponentVisitor, long)

      • forAllComponents

        public void forAllComponents(GVRSceneObject.ComponentVisitor visitor,
                             long componentType)
        Visits all the components of the specified type attached to the descendants of this scene object. The ComponentVisitor.visit function is called for every eligible component of each descendant until it returns false. This allows you to traverse the scene graph safely without copying it. This method gives much better performance than iterating children() or getChildren().
        Parameters:
        visitor - ComponentVisitor interface implementing "visit" function
        componentType - type of component to find
        See Also:
        children(), getChildren(), GVRSceneObject.SceneVisitor, forAllDescendants(SceneVisitor), getComponent(long)

      • forAllComponents

        public void forAllComponents(GVRSceneObject.ComponentVisitor visitor)
        Visits all the components attached to the descendants of this scene object. The ComponentVisitor.visit function is called for every component of each descendant until it returns false. This allows you to traverse the scene graph safely without copying it. This method gives much better performance than iterating children() or getChildren().
        Parameters:
        visitor - ComponentVisitor interface implementing "visit" function
        See Also:
        children(), getChildren(), GVRSceneObject.SceneVisitor, forAllDescendants(SceneVisitor), getComponent(long)

      • getSceneObjectByName

        public GVRSceneObject getSceneObjectByName(java.lang.String name)
        Performs case-sensitive depth-first search
        Parameters:
        name - name of scene object to look for.
        Returns:
        first match in the graph; null if nothing was found or name was null/empty; in case there might be multiple matches consider using getSceneObjectsByName

      • isColliding

        public boolean isColliding(GVRSceneObject otherObject)
        Check if otherObject is colliding with this object.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        true if objects collide, false otherwise

      • isEnabled

        public boolean isEnabled()
        Designates whether the scene object should be displayed or not. If a scene object is marked as not visible, none of its children will be displayed either. This function only controls whether your application wants to display the object and its children. It does not tell you if GearVRf culled the object.
        Returns:
        true if scene object should be displayed, else false.

      • setEnable

        public void setEnable(boolean enable)
        Designates whether the scene object should be displayed or not. If a scene object is not enabled, none of its children will be displayed either.
        Parameters:
        enable - true the object will be displayed, if false it will not be.

      • intersectsBoundingVolume

        public boolean intersectsBoundingVolume(GVRSceneObject otherObject)
        Tests this GVRSceneObject's hierarchical bounding volume against the provided GVRSceneObject's hierarchical bounding volume.
        Parameters:
        otherObject - the GVRSceneObject to check for intersection.
        Returns:
        true if the object intersects with the GVRSceneObjects hierarchical bounding volume, false otherwise.

      • children

        public java.lang.Iterable<GVRSceneObject> children()
        As an alternative to calling getChildrenCount() then repeatedly calling getChildByIndex(int), you can 
         for (GVRSceneObject child : parent.children()) {
 }
        Returns:
        An Iterable, so you can use Java's enhanced for loop. This Iterable gives you an Iterator that does not support Iterator.remove().

        At some point, this might actually return a List<GVRSceneObject>, but that would require either creating an immutable copy or writing a lot of code to support methods like List.addAll(java.util.Collection) and List.clear() - for now, we just create a very light-weight class that only supports iteration.

      • setSensor

        public void setSensor(GVRBaseSensor sensor)
        Add a GVRBaseSensor node to the object. Use null to reset the GVRBaseSensor attached to the GVRSceneObject. Calling setSensor(GVRBaseSensor) when there is already a GVRBaseSensor attached results in the existing GVRBaseSensor being replaced by the new GVRBaseSensor passed to this call. Note that the attached sensor affects this node and its descendants.
        Parameters:
        sensor - The GVRBaseSensor to be added to the object node.

      • getSensor

        public GVRBaseSensor getSensor()
        Get the GVRBaseSensor if available.
        Returns:
        The GVRBaseSensor attached to the node if available, null otherwise.

      • getChildren

        public java.util.List<GVRSceneObject> getChildren()
        Get all the children, in a single list.
        Returns:
        An un-modifiable list of this object's children.
        Since:
        2.0.0
